item.title: InsightConnect Workflow
item.description:
Abstract

This is an overview of the Rapid7 InsightConnect automation that I created collaboratively with Caydon Thomas during my internship at National Heritage Academies (NHA). It reduces that amount of time that security analysts and support technicians spend initiating and tracking endpoint remediation tickets by allowing one to interactively build and submit service requests. Error handling, execution status updates (analogous to return codes), help, and troubleshooting features are built-in.

Diagram

item.title: Intern Presentation
item.description:
Abstract

This presentation was created as part of my internship at National Heritage Academies. Its purpose was to educate other interns about what some of my responsibilities were as an IT Security Analyst and to demonstrate the value of the internship program.

üîç Important

These are the notes pages that I created for my personal use during the presentation. They don’t capture all of the points that I made during the real presentation, but they should give a general idea of what I discussed on each slide.

item.title: Forensics
item.description:
Abstract

This was my final investigation report for a digital forensics class. It focuses on the BTK killer.

üîç Important

The original report contains real pictures of BTK victims. Sensitive images have been censored or removed from this sample.

Preview

item.title: Cyber Event Investigation
item.description:
Abstract

This project was completed for a network security and analysis class. The purpose was to examine suspicious network traffic on a simulated business network. Investigation results are summarized/simplified in a high-level presentation that targets a C-suite audience.

Preview

    / [pdf]

item.title: Capstone Project
item.description:
Abstract

These are the slides and demonstration video for the final group capstone project of my degree. This project was completed collaboratively with Brock Byard and Jacob Derenzy. The goal was to simulate the environment of a security operations center by detecting suspicious network activity (generated by us) related to our assets, and then perform an investigation on the captured information using the tools that we deployed.

Preview

    / [pdf]

Demonstration video (slide 5)

item.title: NICE Challenge Labs
item.description:
Abstract

The NICE Challenge Project intends to provide students with real-world cybersecurity challenges in simulated business environments for workforce development purposes.

I completed the full set of labs with partner analysts in a network security and analysis class. Not all labs are included in the sample below.

Preview

    / [pdf]

item.title: Observing Endpoint IoCs
item.description:
Abstract

This was one of the more in-depth labs from my network security and analysis class. The purpose was to simulate malicious activity and observe any resulting indicators on an endpoint machine.

Preview

    / [pdf]

This is a collection of Wireshark labs that I completed for a network security and analysis class. Lab instructions come from Wireshark 101: Essential Skills for Network Analysis (2nd). Not all labs from the book are included in this sample.

item.title: Applied AI and Machine Learning

Abstract

These samples come from classes regarding the use of machine learning and AI concepts towards solving business problems. Additional samples will be added at a later date.

Samples

These samples are best viewed as HTML exports of the Jupyter Notebooks:

  • Titanic dataset preprocessing/analysis
  • Group model creation project

item.title: ANY.RUN Malware Investigation
item.description:
Abstract

This was a group project where students were tasked with investigating a real malware sample of their choosing using the ANY.RUN malware sandbox. Results are delivered in the form of a blog post.

Our professor gave us permission to submit our project for consideration to be published in the guest category of the official ANY.RUN blog, but it was unfortunately not selected.

If you’re interested, their Q&A with my professor Dr. Jim Furstenburg about cybersecurity education is a good read. He has a lot of great experience and wisdom to share, and the post offers some insights into how the ISIN program at Ferris approaches teaching.
